text: this is Main Street USA or more
precisely main street flushing queens
home to a large and bustling community
of Chinese and Koreans Indians and
options Mexicans and Central Americans
and many others walking these streets
can be an adventure in extraordinary
Asian cuisine the flushing means more
than dumplings and dosas for more than
300 years flushing has been a testing
ground for religious and cultural
freedom you can walk a single block in
flushing like this one and see a
synagogue at back corner the Roman
Catholic Church around that corner a
korean presbyterian church and right
next door to it an Afghan mosque you
want it you got it you got a pipeline if
you get delicious delicious meat and
vegetable buns here City Councilman John
Liu came to flushing in 1972 when he was
five we talked about Flushing's past and
its present and of course we made time
to eat delicious pork buns at his
favorite storefront stand Lujan you can
we have napkins we have seen constant
change over the years where waves of new
people come to flushing revitalize
flushing and then kind of move on to
perhaps greener pastures and new waves
people come back into flushing tell me
about Flushing's history is this Center
for the free expression of religion
flushing is the truth birthplace of
religious freedom
the United States this is where a group
of citizens got together and stood up
for the rights of Quakers or on anybody
really to practice their own religion
councilman Liu is referring to the very
beginnings of flushing the story that
starts here at this house it was built
in or about 1661 by a man named John
Bowne when flushing was just a cluster
of English farms in the Dutch colony of
New Netherland when the first members of
the society of friends were Quakers
arrived here from England in the 1650s
Peter Stuyvesant the director-general of
New Netherland saw them as dangerous
radicals he for bad colonists from
consorting with them in 1657 30 flushing
citizens not Quakers themselves signed a
remarkable letter to Stuyvesant
reminding him that under colonial law
freedom of worship extended to all
faiths that letter became known as the
flushing remonstrance Stuyvesant
responded with arrests and fines for
allowing Quakers to worship in his house
bound was banished from the colony he
successfully argued his case in Holland
and returned here where his family
continued to live until the mid 1940s a
museum since 1947 the house is currently
closed for extensive renovations and
restoration
the Quakers spent 30 years worshiping at
John bounce house before building this
simple meeting house in 1694 on what is
now northern boulevard except for a
period of British occupation during the
Revolutionary War the Society of Friends
have met here every Sunday since Naomi
in this building is 350 years old and it
looks to me looking around like a lot of
this is that old or almost assault what
I'm seeing here yes it is if I came in
here in 1695 to worship it would look
more or less like this real original
glass in some of the windows yeah there
there's one landmarked window and that
has a very very old blown glass I
noticed that there's a sign out front
that's in four languages why because we
welcome people in the neighborhood who
speak those four languages in one of the
English Chinese Korean and Spanish and
people from all of those backgrounds as
well as any other are welcome to join us
in worship if you're interested in
visiting the meeting house and the
beautiful old graveyard behind it it's
open only on sundays at twelve-thirty
p.m. after the sunday meeting
on the same street as John Downes house
but several blocks in three centuries
away stands another symbol of religious
freedom this Hindu temple called in
English the Ganesh tents it's named
after its main deity the elephant-headed
god Ganesh there's been a large and
thriving community of Indian Hindus and
flushing for more than 30 years helping
to continue Flushing's very long
tradition as a place of religious
freedom and tolerance tell me about the
temple how long has this been here this
temple has been here for more than three
decades the consecration of this temple
took place on a very important day for
us that is on 420 like 1977 now we have
one our mailing list more than 20,000
devotees Wow particularly in the
tri-state area and also from all over
the continent the temples main hall is a
simple square room with shrines to
various Hindu gods all around Shiva
Vishnu and others the large central
shrine houses Ganesh the elephant-headed
son of Shiva and Parvati
the temple keeps fruit flowers and
coconuts on hand for worshippers to
offer up to the Goss later when the food
has been blessed by the gods it's
removed from the shrines in place for
anyone can taking home after you feed
the gods you can go next door to the
temple canteen where they'll feed you
traditional indian food paper dosa when
you learn is like a huge paper is going
to come out now if America is the
melting pot this is one of the places
where it's been on a high boil for a
long time absolutely if America is a
melting pot flushing is kind of like the
concentrate that accumulates at the
bottom of the pot
